headline.main: Five Scene-Stealers to Watch: John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph: 'Away We Go'

results.snippet: A look at five breakthrough performances from the summer season, including a soldier, a painter a groomsman and two lovers.
results.lead_paragraph: John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph: 'Away We Go' Sam Mendes's ''Away We Go'' (June 5), a sometimes raucous, sometimes melancholy road movie, concerns the obstacles a young couple who are expecting their first baby encounter in their search for a place to put down roots -- preferably near friends -- and raise a family. Although they aren't planning to tie the knot (her decision), for fans of ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''The Office'' this is a marriage made in comedy heaven, with John Krasinski as the amiable Burt and Maya Rudolph as his bulging beloved, Verona.

headline.main: FIVE SCENE-STEALERS TO WATCH

results.snippet: Jeremy Renner has some memorable good guys on his résumé, most notably the young fireman suffering from depression in ''Twelve and Holding.'' But he is best known for creepy triumphs like Charlize Theron's vicious enemy in ''North Country'' and the...
results.lead_paragraph: Jeremy Renner has some memorable good guys on his résumé, most notably the young fireman suffering from depression in ''Twelve and Holding.'' But he is best known for creepy triumphs like Charlize Theron's vicious enemy in ''North Country'' and the chillingly affectless serial killer in ''Dahmer.'' That sort of gift can trap an actor, but if so, Kathryn Bigelow's suspenseful Iraq war movie, ''The Hurt Locker'' (June 26), should spring Mr. Renner once and for all. Not that his Staff Sgt. William James is just one of the boys. His specialty is disarming the improvised explosive devices -- I.E.D.'s -- that have become the chief killers of troops and civilians. The work is beyond dangerous, but as Mr. Renner plays him, Sergeant James is an enthusiast for this loaded version of Russian roulette. Decked out in his bulky protective gear and formidable helmet, he bounces toward his deadly target like an astronaut on the moon about to discover something wonderful. James's enthusiasm unnerves and infuriates another sergeant (Anthony Mackie), whose task it is to guide and protect him via remote control, and when a younger soldier accuses him of putting them all at risk for an adrenaline high, we see his point. As Mr. Renner plays him, James at first seems like your basic hot dog, flashy and fearless. Certainly he savors his skill at locating and teasing apart the lethal components of the I.E.D.'s; he's dicing with death. But as the story progresses, Mr. Renner gives James a fascinating complexity of macho intensity and guarded tenderness, as well as sly humor and -- surprising in someone who takes a certain pleasure in the discomfort of other men -- a hatred of human cruelty.

headline.main: Q. & A. with Stuart Elliott

results.snippet: Q & A with Stuart Elliott.
results.lead_paragraph: Q: (Reader) I join those who feel that, by using a male voice for the sandwich oven in a new commercial, Quiznos has blown a great opportunity and turned it into a liability.

headline.main: High-Functioning, but Still Alcoholics

results.snippet: As many as half of all alcoholics may be high-functioning types  able to live a successful life in spite of their addictions.
results.lead_paragraph: Sarah Allen Benton is hardly your stereotypical alcoholic. She has a master of science degree from Northeastern University and is a licensed mental health counselor at Emmanuel College in Boston. In recovery from alcoholism for the last five years, she has written an enlightening new book about people like herself, ''Understanding the High-Functioning Alcoholic'' (Praeger Publishers). As Ms. Benton describes them, high-functioning alcoholics are able to maintain respectable, even high-profile lives, usually with a home, family, job and friends. That balancing act continues until something dreadful happens that reveals the truth -- to themselves or to others -- and forces the person to enter a treatment program or lose everything that means anything.

results.abstract: When he closes his eyes at night and drifts off to Slumberland, what does Harvey Keitel see?

headline.main: What Does Harvey Keitel Dream About?

results.snippet: When he closes his eyes at night and drifts off to Slumberland, what does Harvey Keitel see?
results.lead_paragraph: In a fascinating story in Thursday's New York Times, Sarah Kershaw explores a technique that is becoming increasingly popular among actors, in which they use Jungian theories of dream interpretation to enhance their performances and try to act their roles in their dreams before playing them in the waking world.

headline.main: Astronauts Grab Hubble For Repairs

results.snippet: This is the fifth and last of the servicing missions that have repaired, refurbished and reinvented the venerable telescope over the years.
results.lead_paragraph: Hubble got its hug on Wednesday. At 1:14 p.m. Eastern time, as the space shuttle Atlantis and the Hubble Space Telescope sailed over Western Australia, the shuttle's robot arm, with K. Megan McArthur at the controls, reached out, oh, so slowly, and grabbed the telescope.

headline.main: On Hubble Repair Missions, Old and New

results.snippet: It was interesting to hear John Grunsfeld's comment yesterday that Hubble looked "in fantastic shape". Obviously good news. However, the +V3 side of Hubble, which is generally pointed at the Sun, showed the greatest amount of "distress" when we were...
results.lead_paragraph: It was interesting to hear John Grunsfeld's comment yesterday that Hubble looked "in fantastic shape". Obviously good news. However, the +V3 side of Hubble, which is generally pointed at the Sun, showed the greatest amount of "distress" when we were there in 1997 and I don't know how much of that side John would have been able to see. You capture the telescope on the -V3 side. We didn't really notice the damage until sometime after the telescope was berthed. The crew or the ground might have a view of +V3 from the aft bulkhead cameras in the payload bay. The NASA "worm", which is on the top of the telescope on the -V3 side, was showing evidence of peeling in 1997.

headline.main: Transplants Provide New Life For Hubble

results.snippet: The Hubble Space Telescope got new eyes and a new nervous system on Thursday.     It took all of the astronaut Andrew J. Feustel's experience as a mechanic and an old Jaguar restorer, however, to accomplish the eyeball part.
results.lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope got new eyes and a new nervous system on Thursday. It took all of the astronaut Andrew J. Feustel's experience as a mechanic and an old Jaguar restorer, however, to accomplish the eyeball part.

headline.main: Astronauts Replace 16-Year-Old Camera on Hubble

results.snippet: Astronauts begin their mission to fix the Hubble Space Telescope.
results.lead_paragraph: It took all of astronaut Andrew Feustel's experience as a mechanic and an old Jaguar restorer to fit the Hubble Space Telescope with a new set of eyeballs Thursday. The first task of a five-day set of repair and maintenance spacewalks was to install a new camera, the Wide-Field Camera 3, on Hubble. But to get it in, astronauts had to first remove the old camera by unscrewing a seven-foot-long bolt known as the ''A'' latch, which was last moved in 1993 on the first Hubble servicing mission.

results.abstract: Real live astronauts are watching "Star Trek" in outer space - right now.

headline.main: Real Live Astronauts are Watching 'Star Trek' in Outer Space – Right Now

results.snippet: Real live astronauts are watching "Star Trek" in outer space - right now.
results.lead_paragraph: Right about now in outer space, three men are crouched in a node of the International Space Station, watching J.J. Abrams' reboot of "Star Trek" on a laptop. They chose the node, said NASA spokeswoman Nicole Cloutier, because it was "dark and quiet" and would be "a good spot" for three "Star Trek" fans to hunker down for the ultimate viewing experience.

headline.main: Frank Aletter, 83, Screen Actor

results.snippet: The veteran character actor starred in the 1960s situation comedies “Bringing Up Buddy” and “It’s About Time.”
results.lead_paragraph: Frank Aletter, a veteran character actor who starred in the 1960s situation comedies ''Bringing Up Buddy'' and ''It's About Time,'' died on Wednesday at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 83. The cause was cancer, his daughter Kyle Oldham told The Los Angeles Times.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Is Top Candidate to Run NASA

results.snippet: If confirmed, Charles F. Bolden Jr. would be the first African-American to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, but his industry ties could be an issue.

byline.original: By KENNETH CHANG; Sheryl Gay Stolberg contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: Charles F. Bolden Jr., a former space shuttle astronaut and retired Marine major general, is the leading candidate for nomination as the next administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Asked whether an announcement of a nominee would be coming on Monday, the White House secretary, Robert Gibbs, said Friday, ''I think you know that the president will meet with somebody that he hopes will -- wants to meet with somebody about filling the important role of future NASA administrator.''

headline.main: As Tasks at Hubble End, No Tears, but It Was Close

results.snippet: After the fifth and final spacewalk to tune up the Hubble Space Telescope, astronauts offered praise for one another and the engineers and astronomers back on Earth that had made it all possible.
results.lead_paragraph: There is no crying in space, but Monday was perhaps as close as it gets to a blubberfest in space helmets. As he headed into the airlock of the space shuttleAtlantis after the fifth and final spacewalk to tune up the Hubble Space Telescope, the astronaut and astronomer John M. Grunsfeld paused to pay tribute to the telescope and the human spirit.

headline.main: Refurbishments Complete, Astronauts Let Go of Hubble

results.snippet: Practicing a kind of catch-and-release astronomy, the astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis oh-so-gently let the Hubble Space Telescope slip back into the heavens on Tuesday.

results.lead_paragraph: Practicing a kind of catch-and-release astronomy, the astronauts of the space shuttleAtlantis oh-so-gently let the Hubble Space Telescope slip back into the heavens on Tuesday. Reporting to mission control in Houston about 9 a.m. as the telescope and shuttle slowly drifted apart, Scott D. Altman, the Atlantis commander, called the last mission to refurbish the fabled telescope ''an incredible journey'' that demonstrated how humans could overcome challenges by working together.

headline.main: White House Announces Nominee for NASA Administrator

results.snippet: The White House announced on Saturday the nomination of Charles F. Bolden Jr., a former space shuttle astronaut and Marine general, to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.     A White House official, who spoke on the condition of...
results.lead_paragraph: The White House announced on Saturday the nomination of Charles F. Bolden Jr., a former space shuttle astronaut and Marine general, to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A White House official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the decision, said the announcement was timed to take advantage of the attention paid to the current mission of the space shuttle Atlantis; its astronauts made repairs to the Hubble Space Telescope in recent days. The shuttle had been scheduled to return to Earth first on Friday and then on Saturday. With bad weather at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NASA delayed the landing to Sunday.

headline.main: Space Shuttle Is Diverted To California For Landing

results.snippet: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis finally made it home after a voyage of more than 5 million miles.
results.lead_paragraph: As Odysseus learned, getting home can be the hardest part of any journey. Seven astronauts aboard the space shuttleAtlantis finally made it home on Sunday after a voyage of more than five million miles and a two-day wait to return to Earth. After being diverted from its home port in Florida because of bad weather, the Atlantis materialized out of a blue sky over the California desert, looking like a stubby-winged dove, and touched down at Edwards Air Force Base at 11:39 a.m. Eastern time.

headline.kicker: THEATER REVIEW | 'THE SUCCESS OF FAILURE (OR, THE FAILURE OF SUCCESS)'
headline.main: Phasers Aimed At Life's Truths

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: SUCCESS OF FAILURE (OR, THE FAILURE OF SUCCESS), THE (PLAY)

results.snippet: Star-trekking and soul-baring are juxtaposed with bizarre, oddly beguiling bravado in the latest and last installment in Cynthia Hopkins’s trilogy of mixed-media performance works.
results.lead_paragraph: Star-trekking and soul-baring are juxtaposed with bizarre, oddly beguiling bravado in ''The Success of Failure (or, the Failure of Success),'' the latest and last installment in Cynthia Hopkins's trilogy of mixed-media performance works about transforming the harsh truths of life into entertaining fictions. In the trilogy's first two parts, also seen at St. Ann's Warehouse, where the new show opened on Tuesday night, Ms. Hopkins slipped into the skins of Cameron Seymour, a fictional female rock star from the 1970s, and her daughter, a documentary filmmaker searching for the truth about her mother, among other characters. Ms. Hopkins used these fictional selves to explore her ideas about loss, nostalgia and the pursuit of a healthy identity -- and a viable life -- in art.

headline.main: Nominees for the Space Agency

results.snippet: Charles F. Bolden Jr., President Obama’s choice to head NASA, lacks deep expertise in space science and his past ties with the aerospace industry will raise conflict of interest problems.
results.lead_paragraph: President Obama's choice of a former astronaut and retired Marine general, Charles F. Bolden Jr., to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was warmly received by many space enthusiasts and lawmakers. Unfortunately, General Bolden lacks deep expertise in space science and engineering and his past ties with the aerospace industry will raise conflict of interest problems. Before the Senate confirms him, it should probe how well fitted he is to guide the agency through a difficult transition from the space shuttle to follow-on vehicles designed to reach the Moon and beyond.
